https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=318743226

For what Blue Shift is worth, it pulled a couple of story elements that I had questions about from the beginning of Half-Life 2... Like where did Barney come from? Why is he and the rest of the main scientists in 2 working together? It tells an interesting take on the first Half-Life game (though I feel that some aspects didn't make sence.) and answers those previous questions. Definitely a game to look into. The quality wasn't a good as HL1 but the game play is all the same.

The only complain I have is that some of the puzzles weren't so obviouse, and you had to really look around in order to solve things. Sometimes I would get lost on a map and have no clue what to do next. Combined with some light backtracking and you have a set of some really confusing puzzles.

All-in-all it was fun, the pace was nice and it doesn't take all to long to complete. I recomend this to the fans of the series who would like a little bit more half-life. Serriously I'm playing this for the first time in 2019 and and it sort of takes away the sting that we may never have an end to the original story.

Boi oh boi, this game. Well, one day I was thinking "hmm, i got 20‚Ç¨ on steam games! I wonder what to buy!". I bought the half life 1 anthology pack at first, after finishing Half life I saw this game. I thought it would be cool to be Barney, things like protecting scientists and maybe seeing Gordon! So uh... what did this game offer? Well...
First of all, there is no new weapons, wich sucks, couldnt they come up with something creative? not even the meele weapon?
So, the game goes as a meh for me on the story, the final part was a... boring one. Replaybility? A little bit, after finding the chumtoad secret and playing the game on hard and finishing it in 2 days, I could say it has a little bit. One thing that sucks too is that you cant kill as much things as half life, some enemies dont appear and the scientists cant be killed (they "fire" you for that, wich makes sense, but what about Gordon?), oh right.
There is no final boss, welp, thats great. Tbh, the game its ok if you play first half life 1, this game and then Oppsing Force, trust me, you arent gonna regret it, the game does have nods and references to half life 1 and opposing force too, so that makes a reason to stay alert on things. Over all, a neat game, not bad but not great.

Half-Life Blue Shift is the second expansion pack in the HL series and also the shortest which  was originally released 2001. You play as Barney Calhoun and you follow the HL story from his POV which is basically to try and escape the Black Mesa Incident and escape the research facility. 

If you are a fan of the HL universe it is worthy of a place in your games inventory. Do not expect anything too spectacular or a huge development from the original HL storyline. There are no new mechanics or weapons, the puzzles and gameplay are very similar to HL, but what I do like is the interaction between Barney and the other characters as you experience a little more of the HL story around the time of Gordon Freemans appearance at Black Mesa. 

It is not as clean or as graphically impressive as today‚Äôs FPS, but remember it is just under 20 years old, was made as an expansion pack for the vintage FPS game changer HL and forms part of the original HL releases with some updated elements/patches to run on current OS.

Overall it is worth picking this up in a sale for your collection and go back in time for a nostalgic trip down memory lane and how HL began. 

Also worth checking out the walktrough:
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=233166473

The game is decent. It's Half-Life-ish, like a half decent knock-off of the real deal. The art doesn't feel like it's from Valve to me and the Rosenberg's model doesn't fit in with the rest without the HD pack on.

There are invisible walls all over the place, some dialog assumes that Barney is speaking something, and it seems that this game uses things like dynamic lighting a bit too much (it causes the framerate to plummet even with just the flashlight on, at some parts it felt like I was playing the game at 10 FPS). The game is also pretty short compared to Half-Life.

I'd say it's worth a shot if you happen to have it (either already, or you got it in something like the Valve complete pack). I think I saw some of the maps from this game already in the PS2 port of Half-Life.
I don't recall talking to Gordon about beer

In Half-Life: Blue Shift, you play as the titular character Blue Shift played by Arnold Schwartzenegger.  The game centres around the average everyday life of a mall cop/security guard and the challenges and grievances of such a mundane and taxing job and the toll it takes on the human psyche.  So naturally, Aliens invade and the protagonist racks up a human kill-count that rivals that of a Sylvester Stallone movie.  And since the protagonist is played by Arnold Schwartzenegger, Blue Shift can carry upwards of 10+ weapons of varying size and weight without the use of Power Armour or Military Training.

Half-Life: Blue Shift is a wonderful coming of age tale that combines elements of Commando, Falling Down, DOOM and Dora the Explorer to create this magnificent story-driven gem of a game, and for that I give it a big fat perfect score.  Greatest game of the 21st Century, without a shadow of a doubt.

[h1]10/10[/h1]

[h1][b][u]Half-Life: Blue Shift[/u][/b][/h1]

[b]tl;dr =[/b] If you liked Half-Life, buy this game.

[b]Points:[/b] ‚ûä ‚ûã ‚ûå ‚ûç ‚ûé ‚ûè ‚ûê ‚ûë ‚ûà ‚ûâ    [i](8 out of 10)[/i]
[b]Rating:[/b] [u]Good.[/u]
[b]Verdict:[/b] [u]Buy it.[/u]
[b]Seal of approval:[/b] [u]Yes.[/u]

[b]Story:[/b] You are going to see the events that unfolded in Half-Life but from the POV of a Black Mesa Security Officer.

[b]Gameplay:[/b] Same as in Half-Life but with even fewer Puzzles.

[b]Difficulty:[/b] Not that hard.

[b]Features:[/b] Fewer weapons than in Opposing Force.

[b]Duration:[/b] In my Opinion its the shortest Game of the 3. At the time of this review I played it for 5 hours.

[b]Improvements:[/b] Nothing.

[i]This review was written by me. I purchased the game myself and did not recieve a review copy. I did not get payed to review this game.[/i]

- MacTehn

After playing Half-Life, I guess it was inevitable to play this game next when I also had it in my library. My expectations were pretty low knowing it is a half canon game which is made by another developer. I can not tell It was a very good game but i can say that, that it was way better than what i was expecting with some really cool level puzzle ideas which requires you to be aware of environment so it is not just an straightforward expansion. Making player being able to witness the effects of Black Mesa incident from another perspective, it has some very enjoyable moments. Knowing that Calhoun is a character in HL2 it also adds some side stories to the experience.

The game is short but as someone who played both Half-Life and Blue Shift in Hard Mode I must warn you: this game kicks ass of the original in terms of level difficulty: That cool ideas sometimes make you die on and on until you memorize what you gotta do. I don't reccomend to but this game seperately, there are better games to play for sure. But it is like a small extra future in Valve pack and I recommend you to play the game if you have it but if you hate headcrabs you shouldn't play this game. I guess the level designer has an immense fetish of headcrabs.

In the second expansion to Half-Life 1, you play as Barney Calhoun, a security guard at Black Mesa who was present during the events of Half-Life 1.

Unlike Gordon Freeman or Adrian Shephard, Barney doesn't have the HEV suit and has to replenish his armour by picking up Black Mesa Security Helmets or Vest, very akin to Return to Castle Wolfenstein. 

It may be the shortest of the three original Half-Life 1 experiences but its still a fine addition nonetheless.

Witness the events of Half-Life unfold from a different perspective. In Half-Life: Blue Shift, you play as Barney Calhoun who is an security guard employed by the Black Mesa Research Facility as you attempt to reach the surface and ultimately safety from not only the things that spawned due to the resonance cascade but also the Marines sent in to neutralize everyone who was at the Black Mesa facility when the cascade happened.
A short and interesting foray back into the world of Black Mesa. Make sure to pick this one up on sale if you enjoyed the original Half-Life.

Well this is it, the bottom of the half life barrel, if you've played all the games, up to episode 2 and are like me, a broken individual left raw from lack of closure for over 10 years by a profit driven company that has utterly forgotten the fanbase that brought it to success in the first place. *ahem* anyway, blue shift, like opposing force has it's issues *cough*gearbox*cough* but for mod level quality it's pretty good and like I said, it's the bottom of the barrell anyway.

Half Life was launched in 1998 and was a great experience to play, Half Life Opposing Force was launched in 1999 and added a lot of content, a new point of view of the Black Mesa desaster, new guns, new lore, new creatures...  Half Life Blue Shift was launched in 2001 two years later than Opposing Force, and to be honest it is quite dissapointing. First of all there is no new content, everything is recycled from previous games, the only new content he had in this game are a few new models for the scientists like Dr Rosenberg's or the HQ model pack which was later on implemented in both Opposing Force and Half Life, followed by Decay in the PS2 version. Blue Shift can be finished in 2 hours playing on hard mode, so its quite short, however some parts of the game are quite interesting and fun to play, like Xen or the last Chapter "A Leap of Faith". In general this DLC is quite mediocre, but it's still worth playing if you like the original Half Life and want to see the Black Mesa desaster from another point of view.

Final Score: 6
Great expansion. Anything that lets you some more of that classic Half-Life experience is worth your time.

A fun little addition to the Half-Life catalog. Expands the lore by focussing on Barney Calhoun's escape from Black Mesa. Makes you realize that Barney had to deal with zombies and extra-dimensional beings just as much as Gordon. A casual gamer as myself finished it in 3.5 hours.

It's Half-Life 1, but with a worse armour system straight out of DooM, a worse intro than the first game, levels that go downhill quickly, starting with Captive Freight, no fun prototype or alien weapons and an anticlimactic final fight and ending. Still, it's more HL1, so you can't really complain too hard.

While you can get this game on sale for 50 cents, it's hard to justify the 2 hours spent in this hollow "expansion" of the classic. Save your change and download a community addition if you're hungry for more after the main game and Opposing Force. Many are much better constructed and don't leave you wishing you could get time invested back.

It might be impossible to *not* get this expansion anymore, but it's short enough that it doesn't overstay its welcome.  Rather than Freeman, you play as a security officer by the name of Barney Calhoun.  He's also a mute, but unlike Freeman it's easier to explain why he can shoot guns really well.

Like the original Half-Life, there isn't much story here.  The goal/story is to escape the incident going on.  It's a good expansion and the puzzles might be much harder than the original game.  A certain bomb puzzle towards the end comes to mind.  Shooting in Half-Life has never been all that amazing mechanically and nothing changes here, but it does set up some satisfying, scripted moments.  A tank battle comes to mind here.

Grab it along with the original.
